instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SPI_MOSI: What is SPI_MOSI? SPI_MOSI is a signal between the CPU or PCH and the SPI ROM bios chip that is necessary for the machine to POST and boot. If this signal line is corroded or the BIOS chip has failed then you will not get PM_SLP_S4_L and the machine will not boot. Very often this line is corroded by liquid damage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
threads.message:
Hi all.
Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Logic board.

Bought in as not powering on, no lights, display, chimes or fans.
No evidence of liquid ingress - very dusty though.

Found shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> rail.

Removed and that restored Magsafe light and fan- still no chime and no display on internal or external monitor.
SMC reset changes magsafe light.
PRAM reset turns unit on, but doesn't seem to do anything else.

[B]Is <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> vital to functionality?[/B]

I've checked out the voltages of various rails, while the unit was powered on, with battery and display connected. .


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.3V

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 20.0V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20V

<SIGNAL>PP2V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 5.2V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.2V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TBTAPWR</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> 1.87V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> 0.6V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> 1V

[COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)][B]<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0V[/B][/COLOR][B] (Should be 50v?) (Diode mode to ground reads 0.557)[/B]
[COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)][B]<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> 0V[/B][/COLOR][B] (Should be 15-17.8v?) (Diode mode to ground reads 0.518)[/B]
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_TBTLC</SIGNAL> 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_TBTCIO</SIGNAL> 1.1V
[COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)][B]<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4SW_TBTBST_FET</SIGNAL> 0V[/B][/COLOR][B] ( Should be 8.6v) (Diode mode to ground reads 0.451)[/B]
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.8V

[B]Any suggestions as to where to go from here?[/B]
Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
threads.message:
My first suggestion, do not waste time checking voltage for same power rail in different points.
Next suggestion, do not check Thunderbolt area without connecting corresponding device.
Same as for backlight; searching backlight/image on a board which does not even boot???

Missing <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> is not the reason of your problem; replace it anyway.
If it was corroded, reball SMC.

Check SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and traces.
Also clean J6100.
Try known good BIOS.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
threads.message:
Hi again 2informaticos.

Thanks for your suggestions... I'm still learning, as you can probably tell. :)
All good points you make.
I posted all those different voltages in case you wanted them, to save time... but yes... that was a waste of time, lol.

I'll find another <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> equivalent from a dead board and replace it.
No signs of corrosion anywhere.

All the SPI Bus Series Termination resistors measure correct resistance.

However, <SIGNAL>SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> both show zero volts.
The two other SPI lines, <SIGNAL>SPI_MISO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SPI_CS</SIGNAL> both show 3.3 volts.

Another thing I noticed is <RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR> should be 100K Ohms resistance, but shows as only 65.5-74 KOhms.
However, I did test another, admittedly unknown faulty board, and the <RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR> on that one was 74K

I cleaned J6100, despite it looking pristine.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes to 3.35 volts

I'll have a look for the same board to get a BIOS chip off, but thought I'd post this data in the meantime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
threads.message:
Sorry for the delay.
I had to put this on the backburner for a bit.

OK, I replaced the BIOS chip from another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B, and no change. :(
I did notice the CPU is getting very hot.
Still no display internal or external.
SMC reset cycles Magsafe light, power button starts and stops system....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - No display after removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which restored Magsafe light and fan.
threads.message:
Ah. OK.
I think thats probably the most likely.
I'll move on.
Thanks for your help and advice, 2informaticos, I do appreciate it.
